title: James Gunn on Making ‘Superman,’ Not Being Interested in ‘Prestige Projects’ and DC Studios’ Future

body:
James Gunn looks tired but energized as he settles into his chair for the Variety Awards Circuit Podcast, having just flown in from Atlanta. He’s already into pre-production on “Man of Tomorrow,” the follow-up to this summer’s “Superman.” so exhaustion would be expected. Gunn is not only directing the film, but he’s also running DC Studios alongside Peter Safran — an unprecedented balancing act he calls “the hardest movie I’ve ever made.”
	

	The conversation is taking place only two hours before the entertainment landscape shifted, with Netflix announcing an $82 billion acquisition of Warner Bros. — a reminder of how quickly the ground beneath the Hollywood industry, DC, and Gunn himself, continues to move.


	Nonetheless, we’re talking about “Superman,” where Gunn leans in, his eyes brighten and discusses what drew him to the character — which wasn’t the scale or mythology.


	“When I first talked to the cast and crew, I wanted to make something about goodness,” Gunn says. “This guy isn’t perfect, even though he’s Superman. He’s really just trying to do his best. He’s good-natured. He’s loving. He sees the best in everyone.”

	That idea was Superman is not a god, but a sincere, sometimes awkward moral presence. That became Gunn’s anchor — and he credits Grant Morrison’s “All-Star Superman” for crystallizing that approach. “That was the thing that hooked me,” he shares. “That big lug of a superhero being genuinely kind. That’s what I took from the book.”

	Unlike the relative freedom Gunn had with “Guardians of the Galaxy,” Superman came with a century’s worth of expectations, and of course, disagreements. “Everyone in the world thinks something different about Superman. Everybody knows who he is.”
	

	The scrutiny extended beyond the cape. Gunn was aware that this film would be viewed as a referendum on the future of DC itself. “There were all the eyes on us — on DC, on the DCU, on everything,” he says. “That pressure was real.”

	Casting, then, was non-negotiable. “If I couldn’t find Superman, I wasn’t going to make the movie,” Gunn says flatly. David Corenswet was the second audition he saw. “I remember thinking, ‘If that’s the worst we do, we’re in great shape.’”

	What emerged is a film that leans toward optimism at a moment when superhero cinema has often favored grit. Gunn’s Superman isn’t naïve, but he is hopeful. Coming off the year we all had, that choice feels quite radical.

	On this episode of the Variety Awards Circuit Podcast, Gunn talks about his process of making “Superman,” why he’ll never chase a prestige projects and what to expect from “Man of Tomorrow.”



	

									Screengrab courtesy of DC Studios
	



	Read excerpts from her interview below, which has been edited and condensed for clarity.

	What made “Superman” the hardest film you’ve directed?

	This was the hardest movie I’ve ever made. The next hardest was probably the first “Guardians.” With “Guardians,” you were building a corner of the universe that felt completely different from everything else Marvel was doing at the time. Here, I was reorienting something everyone already thinks they understand. Strangely, it’s the most comic-book-driven thing I’ve ever done. More than any of my other superhero films.

	How did assembling your creative team shape the film?

	I’ve worked with many of these people for years. Beth Mickel, my production designer, has been with me on the last three films. Steph Ceretti has overseen visual effects for multiple projects now. Being in charge of DC meant I could finally keep the team together instead of losing people between films. That continuity matters.

	What were you most proud of in the visual effects, especially with Krypto the Dog?

	Framestore’s work on Krypto is extraordinary. I’ll put those shots up against anything I’ve ever seen. ILM was incredible as well. It was just a world-class group of artists working at the highest level.

	How does it feel to be both a filmmaker and a studio head at the same time?
	

	I don’t think it’s ever really been done. Even Walt Disney was more of a producer than a director. It’s an experiment. And yes, sometimes it probably sounds like madness — especially since I don’t make the most conventional films. But I love big spectacle. That’s my jam. I originally said no to the job. I didn’t want to do what Kevin Feige does. But once Peter and I realized we’d be doing it together, it became exciting. I still don’t know if it’s sustainable long-term. It’s a lot. There just aren’t enough hours in the day.

	What films made you fall in love with movies?

	I think the first movie I saw in a theater was “The Aristocats.” Then “The Strongest Man in the World” with Kurt Russell. But it was “Star Wars” that completely changed me. That feeling of entering another world. And then “Raiders of the Lost Ark” made me aware of filmmakers themselves — George Lucas, Steven Spielberg. That’s when it clicked.

	How do you think about prestige versus mainstream filmmaking?

	I don’t care about prestige. I mean, sure, would it be cool to be nominated for Best Director or something? Yeah, would I rather have that than not? But it’s not really my concern. Occasionally I have ideas that are more independent movies, but I like making the kind of movies that I make, and I like making pop cinema, for lack of a better term. If I can have those things also be something that are emotionally resonant to people, or affect people in a deeper, more spiritual way, like a lot of people have told me that “Superman” did, a lot of people have told me that “Guardians 3” did, then that’s fantastic. That’s what I would love to be able to do. But I like making the big movies too. There’s an artistry to it, the creative flow. But then I also like the part of it that’s putting the big puzzle together and creating this machine that works for an audience to elicit a reaction from them, whether it’s emotional, whether it’s laughter, whether it’s screaming, whether it’s whatever it is. That’s the fun part of it.

	Why did “Guardians of the Galaxy” feel like the right leap into big-budget filmmaking?

	I had walked away from another studio project because they stripped everything personal out of it. Then “Guardians” came along and I thought, no one else can make this movie the way I can. I wanted to make a space opera. I love raccoons. It felt completely me. That’s always been my goal — to make big movies that still feel personal.
	

	What can you tell us about “Man of Tomorrow?”

	At its core, it’s about Clark and Lex. I relate to both of them. I relate to Lex’s ambition and obsession — minus the murder. And I relate to Superman’s belief in people, his Midwestern values. They’re two sides of me. 

	What does your partnership with Peter Safran bring to DC Studios?

	Peter’s the best. He does everything I don’t do well. He keeps the ship steady, keeps everyone aligned, connects us with Jim Lee and the comics side, and unifies departments that used to operate separately. What we share is a genuine love for these characters. We know what a privilege it is to help shape how people see them now — and that responsibility is something we take seriously.

	Variety’s “Awards Circuit” podcast, hosted by Clayton Davis, Jazz Tangcay, Emily Longeretta, Jenelle Riley and Michael Schneider, who also produces, is your one-stop source for lively conversations about the best in film and television. Each episode, “Awards Circuit” features interviews with top film and TV talent and creatives, discussions and debates about awards races and industry headlines, and much more. Subscribe via Apple Podcasts, Stitcher, Spotify or anywhere you download podcasts.

title: Chevy Chase Says ‘I’m Not Racist’ When Asked About ‘Community’ Exit: The Show ‘Wasn’t a Bad Experience. I Just Didn’t Think It Was That Good’

body:
Chevy Chase recently took part in a joint interview with The New York Times alongside Marina Zenovich, the director of the new CNN documentary “I’m Chevy Chase and You’re Not,” and was asked about how the film depicts Chase’s tumultuous stint on “Community.” Chase had a series regular role on the NBC sitcom and exited after Season 4 amid a public spat with creator Dan Harmon over creative differences and an incident in which he allegedly said the N-word on set.
	

	“It wasn’t a bad experience. I just didn’t think it was that good, the show,” Chase told The Times about the series. 


	When asked how he felt about his role ending, Chase answered: “I thought it ended great.”

	“It was too great a misunderstanding of what I was saying and not saying,” Chase then added about his exit. “I thought that there was at least one person — and another who, for some ungodly reason, didn’t get me, didn’t know who I was, or didn’t realize for one second I’m not racist. They were too young to be aware of my work. Instead, there was some sort of visceral reaction from them.”

	As recounted in the documentary and by The Times: “During production of Season 4, Chase became frustrated with his character’s increasing bigotry, in particular with a story line in which the character does a bit with a blackface hand puppet. The documentary recounts allegations that Chase, in frustration, asked whether his character would next be made to use a racial slur, and reportedly uttered that slur in reference. He abruptly exited the show.”

	“Community” director Jay Chandrasekhar is interviewed in the documentary and says Chase had a “meltdown” on set after an incident, in which he allegedly used the N-word on set, leaked to the press. The alleged incident occurred between Chase and co-star Yvette Nicole Brown, with Chandrasekhar explaining: “I know that there was a history between [Chevy and Yvette] around race, and she got up and stormed out of there. Chevy storms off, so the producer is like, ‘We need Yvette in the scene, right?’ I’m like, ‘Yeah, she’s in the next scene.’ And he goes, ‘Well, she won’t come out unless Chevy apologizes to her.’”
	

	Chandrasekhar said Chevy eventually returned to the set but claimed he “didn’t say anything” to upset Brown, adding: “[Chevy] goes, ‘You know, me and Richard Pryor, I used to call Richard Pryor the N-word, and he used to call me The Honky, and we loved each other.’ And I’m like, ‘I know, man, I love that bit.’ I said, ‘You know, can we just have a little apology?’ He goes, ‘For what?’”

	The incident was later reported on by The Hollywood Reporter, who claimed Chase was “frustrated” with his character arc and used the N-word “when questioning the dialogue.” The report stressed that Chase did not use the racial slur directly at his Black co-stars Brown and Donald Glover, although both actors were reportedly on set at the time.

	Chandrasekhar said that when production resumed after the THR story broke, Chase arrived on set and had a “full meltdown” as he came “storming onto the set, and he goes, ‘Who fucked me over?’ … My career is ruined! I’m ruined!’ Like, it’s a full meltdown. ‘Fuck all of you!’ And I’m like, ‘Alright, let’s shoot the scene.’ He never ended up coming back after that.”

	Zenovich previously told Variety that she tried to get more of Chase’s “Community” cast members and crew members to participate in the documentary, but “every single person said no” because “there are things people don’t want to talk about.”

	As the “Community” incident resurfaced due to “I’m Chevy Chase and You’re Not,” Yvette Nicole Brown took to Instagram and appeared to address it by writing: “There are things I’ve never spoken of publicly and perhaps never will. Anyone currently speaking FOR or ABOUT me with perceived authority is speaking without EVER speaking to me about the things they claim to know about. They actually don’t really know me at all.”

	Donald Glover notably told The New Yorker in 2018 that Chase repeatedly made racist jokes on the “Community” set. Chase, meanwhile, told CBS Sunday Morning in 2022 that he “doesn’t give a crap” about headlines and former co-stars painting him as problematic on set, adding at the time: “I don’t give a crap. I am who I am. And I like who I am. I don’t care. And it’s part of me that I don’t care. And I’ve thought about that a lot. And I don’t know what to tell you, man. I just don’t care.”
	

	Head over to The New York Times’ website to read Chase’s latest interview in its entirety.

		Prince’s ‘When Doves Cry’ and ‘Purple Rain’ Spotify Streams More Than Double in ‘Stranger Things’ Series Finale Surge
	
	
			


			
			
	

									AFP via Getty Images
	

		
	
				
	Prince is seeing a significant Spotify streaming boost in his catalog thanks to key syncs in the series finale of “Stranger Things.”

	Since the episode debuted on New Year’s Eve, “Purple Rain” has seen a 243 percent increase in Spotify global streams and a 577 percent surge in global Gen-Z streams specifically, Variety can exclusively reveal. “When Doves Cry” also saw a 200 percent boost in global streams, as well as a 128 percent increase in Gen Z streams. Overall streams of Prince‘s catalog have climbed 190 percent, with an 88 percent uptick in Gen Z streams.
	

	“When Doves Cry” and “Purple Rain” were featured at pivotal moments in the finale. When the “Stranger Things” heroes set the explosives to destroy the Upside Down for once and for all, they put on Side Two of “Purple Rain,” which starts with “When Doves Cry” and ends with the title track. It’s “Purple Rain” that’s playing as Eleven (Millie Bobbie Brown) appears to sacrifice herself when she brings Mike (Finn Wolfhard) into her mind to say a final goodbye.


	Notably, the two songs have not been used in a TV series since Prince included them on the soundtrack for his 1984 film “Purple Rain.” “We were told that it was a real long shot, so we just crossed our fingers,” series creator Matt Duffer told Tudum following the finale premiere.

	Co-creator Ross Duffer said that they had “never talked about a song choice as much as we did for that moment. What is also very exciting about it is it just has not been used. [Prince’s] estate does not generally allow that song to be licensed outside of the ‘Purple Rain’ movie.”

title: French Government Defends George and Amal Clooney Citizenship: ‘They Contribute’ to ‘International Influence and Cultural Outreach’

body:
Not everyone is happy about George Clooney and his family becoming French citizens. The recent news of Clooney, his wife Amal and their children being granted French citizenship sparked criticism from Marie-Pierre Vedrenne, a junior deputy to the interior minister, who argued in a radio interview on Franceinfo that it raised an “issue of fairness.”

	Vedrenne suggested that Clooney had been granted French citizenship due to his fame rather than on merit, and she argued “this is not the right message to send.” She also said she felt that it showed some ”double standards” and added that she will verify “the entire procedure,” according to Le Monde newspaper. But shortly after Vedrenne’s comments, the interior minister Laurent Nuñez fought back the accusations of Vedrenne — with whom he works closely — saying that Clooney and his wife Amal were naturalized “by decree,” from a “decision of the public authority.” Nunez also said Clooney’s naturalization was “a great chance for our country.”
	

	The ministry of foreign affairs also reacted to the bashing over Clooney, arguing that the government “followed a rigorous procedure ranging from security checks to regulatory naturalization interviews at the prefecture, including the payment of tax stamps.”

	“Like many French people, we are delighted to welcome George and Amal Clooney to the national community,” said the ministry, who cited the civic code which allows “any foreigner … who contributes through their distinguished actions to the influence of France and the prosperity of its international economic relations” to gain access to French citizenship.
	

	Clooney, who lives in Brignoles in the South of France with his family, recently joked while promoting Netflix’s “Jay Kelly” on the local pay TV channel Canal+ that his French was “horrible.” He said his wife and kids, meanwhile, speak French fluently. “They speak French in front of me so that they can say terrible things about me to my face, and I don’t know,” he said. Clooney previously told the French radio RTL in an interview in December, “I love the French culture, your language, even if I’m still bad at it after 400 days of courses.”

	U.S. President Donald Trump, meanwhile, took the opportunity to mock Clooney after the news of his citizenship. “Good News! George and Amal Clooney, two of the worst political prognosticators of all time, have officially become citizens of France which is, sadly, in the midst of a major crime problem because of their absolutely horrendous handling of immigration,” Trump said on Truth Social.

	However, Clooney is already in the midst of contributing to the French entertainment industry by filming a cameo in the “Call My Agent!” movie spinoff, which is produced by Mediawan for Netflix.

title: Victoria Jones, Tommy Lee Jones’ Daughter, Found Dead at 34
description: Victoria Jones, the daughter of Tommy Lee Jones who acted and appeared with her father in two of his films, was found dead at a San Francisco hotel
body:
Victoria Jones, the daughter of Tommy Lee Jones who acted and appeared with her father in two of his films, was found dead at a San Francisco hotel on Thursday, Jan. 1, according to NBC Bay Area. She was 34.

	The San Francisco Fire Department released a statement to media outlets saying that paramedics were called to the Fairmont Hotel in San Francisco at 2:52 a.m on New Year’s Day.

	“Our units responded to the scene, performed an assessment and declared one person deceased,” a spokesperson said. A cause of death is not yet known.
	

	“We are deeply saddened by an incident that occurred at the hotel on January 1, 2026,” the Fairmont Hotel said in a statement to NBC Bay Area. “Our heartfelt condolences are with the family and loved ones during this very difficult time. The hotel team is actively cooperating and supporting police authorities within the framework of the ongoing investigation.”

	Victoria acted as a child opposite her father in “Men in Black II” in 2002 and “The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada” in 2005. The latter was Tommy Lee Jones’ directorial debut, in which he also starred. She also appeared in the 2005 film “Sorry, Haters,” an episode of “One Tree Hill” and the 2014 film “The Homesman” as an adult.

	Victoria accompanied her father to several movie premieres and red carpets during his career. Tommy Lee Jones became an Oscar winner in 1994 for “The Fugitive” and most recently appeared in “The Burial” and “Finestkind” in 2023.

	Variety has reached out to Tommy Lee Jones’ representative. Victoria was the second child of Tommy Lee Jones and his second wife, Kimberlea Cloughley.

title: From Will Arnett to Lucy Liu,  Performances That Shouldn’t Be Overlooked this Awards Season
description: As the year comes to a close, many standout actors have garnered attention. Of course, only a select few will continue on to Oscar glory — 20 to be
body: As the year comes to a close, many standout actors have garnered attention. Of course, only a select few will continue on to Oscar glory — 20 to be exact. But there are many notable performances that, while well-received, have yet to be recognized by top awards associations. Here, we make a case for 12 actors who deserve consideration.Will ArnettIs This Thing On?Arnett gets to flex his dramatic muscles in Bradley Cooper’s comedy-drama. As his marriage to Tess (Laura Dern) crumbles, Alex (Arnett) finds a creative and psychological outlet in stand-up comedy. While we expect Arnett to nail the comedy bits, he’s loving, confused, hurt and defiant in a scene with Dern in his bachelor pad. He has an old photo of Tess in her heyday on the volleyball court blown up and framed, but the angle is from behind. He says it shows their sons what a badass their mom is; she explodes because it doesn’t show her face. The scene encapsulates all the issues in their marriage and both play it with heartbreaking poignancy.Miles CatonSinnersDirector Ryan Coogler describes Caton as an “once-in-a-lifetime voice,” and he’s not wrong. It’s certainly impressive when Caton, who plays the preacher’s son, Sammie, in “Sinners,” teases his vocals in the back of a car ride, but when he steps on stage for a big musical number, his singing blows the roof off the joint. Literally! It’s a memorable and captivating debut performance with Caton showing off his singing and acting chops.Oona ChaplinAvatar: Fire and Ash“Game of Thrones” alum Oona Chaplin is Pandora’s newest villain, Varang, the main antagonist leading the Ash people in James Cameron’s “Avatar: Fire and Ash.” Chaplin’s Varang is fiery and thrilling to watch. She’s a highlight of the film — certainly with her powerful physicality, flashing eyes and stunning headdress, it’s hard to take your eyes off her. Varang is terrifying, but her drive to save her people makes her a hero. And maybe, Varang isn’t the bad guy after all. Hopefully, the next installment gives Varang and Chaplin more time to shine and help understand her origin story.Kerry CondonTrain DreamsLike Heath Ledger’s closed-off cowboy in “Brokeback Mountain,” Joel Edgerton’s taciturn Robert Grainier in “Train Dreams” struggles to put his feelings into words, retreating into himself after his wife dies. When Condon enters the picture, playing a widow who comes along at a moment when the wounded logger appears to have lost his purpose, she brings grace and warmth to the equation. Even just sitting quietly at his side, the Irish actress conveys the healing power of human connection in several quietly profound scenes that course-correct his attitudes on life.Billy CrudupJay KellyWhile his co-star Adam Sandler is rightfully being recognized for his standout supporting role in the film, Crudup also delivers a master class in just a few minutes of screen time. Crudup plays Timothy, a counterpart of George Clooney’s titular movie star who never made it as an actor and sees his old friend as having taken the glory he deserved. As the two catch up, Crudup veers from good-natured to sorrowful to bitter to menacing in a matter of minutes. It’s no coincidence that even when he’s offscreen, his character haunts the rest of the story.Abel FerraraMarty SupremeThe “Bad Lieutenant” helmer gives his Ezra Mishkin an unexpected arc: he at first seems like a doddering old man down on his luck who’s overly attached to his dog. But by the time events with Timothée Chalamet’s Marty come to a head, Ferrara has drawn a sinister character — a gangster with a hair-trigger finger on his gun who will kill to get back his dog and money, in that order. While Ferrara’s gangster is chilling, a climactic shootout in a farmhouse allows him to play Mishkin as the lead in the blackest of comedies.Jacobi JupeHamnetJupe might not be eligible for a SAG ensemble nomination due to technicalities, but he won over audiences in Chloé Zhao’s “Hamnet” as the titular character. He plays the young son of William Shakespeare (Paul Mescal) and wife Agnes (Jessie Buckley). In the film, his dad has to travel to London for work and tells his son to “be brave.” Hamnet takes those words to heart and sacrifices his life for his sister’s. Jupe delivers one of the best child performances of the year. He’s charming as a young boy who aspires to follow in his dad’s footsteps, and act. But he pulls out all the stops for the death scene and breaks your heart as he promises to be brave and face death.Lucy LiuRosemeadLiu has always been a scene-stealer, be it the slapstick comedy of “Ally McBeal” or in action pics like “Kill Bill.” What’s particularly impressive about her work in “Rosemead” is how immediately you buy her as the grounded character of Irene, a Chinese immigrant. When she learns her cancer is terminal and her schizophrenic son will soon be legal age, she is driven to a desperate choice that might seem unthinkable. But in Liu’s hands, you never doubt Irene’s love and you can empathize with her impossible plight. It’s a timely, urgent film made all the more harrowing knowing it’s based on a true story.Jay LycurgoSteveAs ensemble acting goes, Netflix’s “Steve” is a knockout, collecting roughly a dozen unfamiliar young performers to play rowdy reform-school cases opposite Cillian Murphy’s unravelling headmaster. The novel that inspired “Steve” was actually named for Lycurgo’s character, Shy, who can turn from tender and introspective one moment to frighteningly aggressive on a dime. Lycurgo did earn a British Independent Film Award for his remarkable, unpredictable performance, but the young actor deserves further accolades. He succeeds in keeping audiences on edge, while also generating empathy for his troubled character.Vahid MobasseriIt Was Just an AccidentIranian actor Mobasseri starred in helmer Jafar Panahi in 2022’s “No Bears,” and here, the revered director casts him as a mechanic whose determination to extract retribution on his jailer is at once chilling, stomach-churning and even funny. Mobasseri plays Vahid as a relatable everyman that the audience latches onto — he is our surrogate. But Mobasseri infuses Vahid with decency that overcomes a thirst for revenge, and in the end, his fear is a startling reminder to not yield to oppression.Sarah NilesF1Niles, as Bernadette, the mother of driving phenom Joshua (Damson Idris), brings charm, savvy and most importantly, a large well of confidence and love for her son to “F1.” It’s not so much one moment with her character, it’s the way her spirit threads through the film: she believes in her son’s talent more than he believes in it. She’s a rock, and when she tells off Sonny (Brad Pitt) — blaming him for her son’s crash during a race — she combines Mama Bear fury and admirable restraint to let Sonny and the audience know that this woman is not to be messed with.TonatiuhKiss of the Spider WomanStraight and white, William Hurt won an Oscar for his then-revolutionary turn as Molina in Hector Babenco’s non-musical 1985 film. But when it came time for Bill Condon to cast the role in his adaptation of the Kander and Ebb show, the “Dreamgirls” director (who previously launched Jennifer Hudson to Oscar glory) searched practically the whole Western hemisphere and found his Molina in Mexican American actor Tonatiuh, who interprets the character’s queer identity quite differently, tapping into more contemporary notions of gender fluidity. Tonatiuh’s Molina can be frivolous one moment, maternal the next, appearing clean-cut, closeted and Cary Grant-like in the fantasy numbers.

									Davies Jr.: Getty Images; Lighton: Oliver Holms
	

		
	
				

	When Sean Baker’s “Anora” won both the Palme d’Or at Cannes — followed by best picture at the Oscars — those honors reinforced what Variety had been saying a decade earlier, when the filmmaker appeared on the publication’s 10 Directors to Watch list, before “Tangerine” had even premiered at Sundance. The same goes for Chloé Zhao, winner of the audience prize at this year’s Toronto International Film Festival for “Hamnet,” who was selected for her earlier film “The Rider.”

	Those names join the likes of Christopher Nolan, Coralie Fargeat, Jonathan Glazer, Ruben Östlund, Wes Anderson, Alfonso Cuarón, Steve McQueen and Benh Zeitlin, who were all named “directors to watch” by Variety far in advance of being nominated for best director at the Academy Awards. Not that the distinction is reserved only for awards contenders. The aim is to represent the incredible range of up-and-coming talent in all respects, encompassing a wide range of budgets, genres and identities.

	On this year’s list, you’ll find a mix of American-made and international directors, including two with films submitted to the Oscar international feature category (“My Father’s Shadow” and “Happy Birthday”), a handful of independent films world premiering at the Sundance Film Festival later this month (“If I Go Will They Miss Me,” “Josephine” and “Run Amok”) and three stellar debuts from the Cannes Film Festival, where actress Kristen Stewart premiered her first feature behind the camera, “The Chronology of Water.”


			
			
	Akinola Davies Jr.
			
										
					Image Credit: Getty Images				
					
				

	“My Father’s Shadow”

	Unlike for a lot of people, 2025 has been a pretty great year for Akinola Davies Jr. His feature debut, “My Father’s Shadow,” won a Camera d’Or special mention at Cannes and went on to be nominated for 12 British Independent Film Awards, winning best director. Davies wrote the film with his brother Wale, a rapper and poet. “He’s really literal,” Davies says, “whereas I think in pictures, so we complement each other.”

	“My Father’s Shadow” follows two boys and their somewhat absent dad as he takes them into Lagos, Nigeria, from their rural village on a pivotal day — the 1993 election, the country’s first since a 1983 military coup.

	“Fundamentally, we were just trying to make a film for ourselves and by ourselves,” says Davies, who was born in London but grew up in Nigeria. Through a more nuanced perspective, Davies is committed to offering “representations of the world that we know and see as honest and not as stereotypical,” he says. “We’re the diaspora of Nigerians and Africans authoring our own stories. We think that’s quite important, because often, our stories are authored by people from other parts of the world.”

	As for what kind of films he’d like to make in the future, Davies laughs and says, “On any given day, I have a different answer to that question.” He wants to continue to mine the creative partnership he has with his brother. “But what drives me,” he says, “is to tell stories that we haven’t seen before. Whether it’s a thriller, a romance, a horror film or an action film, I just want to make things from a slightly different perspective.”

	— Carole Horst

	Influences: Steven Spielberg, Hirokazu Kore-eda, early Spike Lee, early Julie DashManagement: Lark Management

		
			
			
	Beth de Araújo
			
										
					Image Credit: Ava Berkofsky				
					
				

	“Josephine”

	Beth de Araújo loves to write — she says it centers her — but 11 years ago, she realized there was a personal story burning inside her that she had to tell. 

	“One day, I was pretty deeply triggered by something, and I couldn’t write anything else,” says de Araújo, explaining the impetus to compose “Josephine,” a work of autobiographical fiction about an 8-year-old who witnesses a rape at her local park. “I experienced something at a very young age, and my fear and hypervigilance around sexual assault was very real and present through my life.”

	De Araújo’s on-screen proxy is newcomer Mason Reeves, whom she discovered by canvassing a farmer’s market in her native San Francisco. “It was magic when her audition tape came in,” the filmmaker says. “She’s never acted before, but she’s an incredibly smart and emotionally intelligent person.”

	The director then recruited Channing Tatum and Gemma Chan for the roles of Josephine’s parents. “It is not often you find A-list cast that will play second on the callsheet to an 8-year-old unknown actor,” de Araújo says. “I find that very heartwarming.”

	The drama, de Araújo’s second feature after the single-shot thriller “Soft & Quiet,” will make its world premiere at the Sundance Film Festival, which brings her full circle after developing the material through the Sundance directors’ lab. Among her fondest memories is “listening to Robert Redford pick apart my scenes in the most loving way because he cared enough to critique them.”

	With this tale now told, de Araújo is eager to take on new challenges. “I would like to try my hand at bigger world-building,” she says, looking forward to “the production designer and me having some time to build a world we do not live in.”

	— Angelique Jackson

	Influences: Jacques Audiard, Denis Villeneuve, Ryan Coogler, Debra GranikAgency: WMELegal: Frankfurt Kurnit Klein & Selz

		
			
			
	Jan-Ole Gerster
			
										
					Image Credit: Daniel Poller				
					
				

	“Islands”

	Ever since he shook up the German film scene with his indie feature debut, “Oh Boy,” Jan-Ole Gerster has been recognized as an actors’ director — someone who generates a synergistic atmosphere on set, so that every role results in a complex, recognizable human being. “For me, working with actors is the most inspiring part of the filmmaking process,” Gerster says. “I love collaborating with them to shape a distinct character and bring their story to the screen.”

	The scrappy black-and-white movie that launched actor Tom Schilling’s career, “Oh Boy” (which was retitled “A Coffee in Berlin” in the U.S.), surprised many in 2012, earning six Lolas (the German Film Academy prize) over big-budget “Cloud Atlas.”

	Gerster now aims to work more internationally. His latest film, the sunlit noir “Islands,” was shot in English with English actors Sam Riley and Stacy Martin on Spain’s Fuerteventura. Reviewing the film at the 2025 Berlin Film Festival, Variety called it “Something just psychosexual enough for Patricia Highsmith to have written.”

	During Gerster’s youth in smalltown North Rhine-Westphalia, a video store was his window into the world of cinema. Later, he took a job at Berlin’s X-Filme Creative Pool, which produced “Run Lola Run.”This practical experience earned him a place at Berlin’s prestigious DFFB film school. “Film school was a fantastic field for experimentation — a protected space where you could try things out, fail and start all over again,” he says.

	Gerster is currently developing two scripts, one of which, a psychological dark comedy, is set internationally.

	— Alissa Simon

	Influences: John Cassavetes and Gena Rowlands, the Coen brothers, Bob Dylan, Federico Fellini

		
			
			
	Sarah Goher
			
										
					Image Credit: Cherine Shiha				
					
				

	“Happy Birthday”

	Born and raised in the Bronx, Egyptian American writer-director Sarah Goher knew in high school that she wanted to be a filmmaker. As a student at the Nightingale -Bamford School, Goher found inspiration in a videomaking class, but even more formative was her realization post-9/11 that barely any films or TV shows reflected her culture. But now she is at the forefront of that representation — her directing debut “Happy Birthday” is Egypt’s pick for the international feature Oscar.

	Inspired by Goher’s childhood visits to her grandmother, “Happy Birthday” illuminates disparities of wealth and class in contemporary Cairo through the story of a resourceful 8-year-old maid whose devoted friendship with the daughter of the household she works for is discouraged by her employers.The film premiered at the Tribeca Film Festival, where it earned awards for best international narrative feature and screenplay, as well as the Nora Ephron award for a distinguished female filmmaker. Since then, it has been traveling the festival circuit and garnering audience awards from Mill Valley to El Gouna.

	Although “Happy Birthday” marks Goher’s first feature as a director, she boasts an extensive résumé as a writer-producer, having worked in collaboration with her husband, Mohamed Diab, on his films “Cairo 678,” “Clash” and “Amira,” as well as the Marvel TV limited series “Moon Knight.”

	She already has two additional features in development. One is a science-fiction story from a child’s perspective. The second, she says, “is set around the first female serial killers in history — who are Egyptian.”

	Goher’s dream project is a modern take on Hatshepsut, ancient Egypt’s most prosperous pharaoh. Applying the sardonic tone of Sylvia Plath’s “The Bell Jar” to the distaff leader, she aims to make “a dark comedy about the most important and understated woman in ancient civilization, whose successors tried desperately to erase her from history.”

	— Alissa Simon

	Influences: “The Red Balloon,” “The 400 Blows,” “Cinema Paradiso”Legal: Greenberg Glusker

		
			
			
	Dave Green
			
										
					Image Credit: Karen Kuehn				
					
				

	“Coyote vs. Acme”

	Looking back, Dave Green recognizes the irony: “I think I was in self-protection mode after the previous experience I’d had [directing “Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows”], and I was just wanting to be very careful about who I was going to work with next,” he says, describing the excitement he felt pitching Warner Bros. his take on Ian Frazier’s satirical “Coyote v. Acme” piece, first published in The New Yorker, in which Wile E. Coyote sues the company that manufactured all his faulty equipment.

	“Pretty much all of the Looney Tunes movies that had ever been made are ensemble movies,” he says. “They are ‘The Avengers,’ basically. But I felt like they’d never made the ‘Iron Man’ of the Looney Tunes movies, and I felt like there was an opportunity there to get to know one character in a really intimate way. And then from there, we can cameo and showcase the other characters.”

	Samy Burch wrote the script, and Green worked out an elaborate previs presentation, in which hand-drawn characters appeared alongside flesh-and-blood actors (Will Forte would later be cast as the shaggy lawyer representing Coyote), so execs could picture the film Green had in mind. The studio loved the idea, partnering him with producer Chris DeFaria, who had live action/animation hybrid experience from “Tom & Jerry.”

	Making the film was a blast, insists Green, whose creative blending of beloved characters (including deep cuts for super-fans) with live-action footage recalls “Who Framed Roger Rabbit.” The sense of humor is similarly anarchic: “I felt like that edginess was always a defining element of the Warner Bros. cartoons over Disney stuff,” Green says.

	Then, just when the film was finished, the studio bean counters decided to bury the project, choosing to take a tax write-off instead — a tough break for Green, who had bypassed film school, working as an assistant for Sam Raimi on “Spider-Man 3” after getting his American Studies degree at UC Berkeley. 

	His Amblin-esque 2014 debut, “Earth to Echo,” explored the bond between three boys and a hovering, mostly-computer-generated droid. Then came the “TMNT” sequel, a crash course in motion capture for a young filmmaker hungry for such challenges. “Coyote vs. Acme” was supposed to be the solution to the compromises made on that film. Fortunately, Warner Bros. sold the rights to Ketchup Entertainment, which will release the film in August. Meanwhile, Green is being careful about his next project.

	“I’m always looking to do something I haven’t done before, and getting to stretch into new areas,” says Green, who’s developing an R-rated high school party movie called “Hex” that has a supernatural element to it. “Everything I’m chasing these days is darker, allowing me to step outside the family space.”

	— Peter Debruge

	Influences: Steven Spielberg, Tim Burton, the Coen brothers, Sam RaimiAgency: UTAManagement: Kaplan/PerroneLegal: Hirsch Wallerstein Hayum Matlof + Fishman

		
			
			
	Chandler Levack
			
										
					Image Credit: Getty Images for IMDb				
					
				

	“Mile End Kicks”

	Working as a rock critic in her early 20s, Chandler Levack reserved Sunday nights for a different art. “‘Girls’ was my film school,” she says. “I was the same age as Lena Dunham, and I wanted to become a writer-director, so I’d watch each episode to dissect the choices: ‘OK, they’re cutting to the wide. Why?’”

	Levack carried that curiosity into her first two features, “I Like Movies” and “Mile End Kicks,” drawing on her suburban Ontario adolescence and early Montreal journalism years to portray her own generation with intimacy, candor and — most crucially — hindsight.

	“You need distance,” she says. “I wrote the first draft of ‘Mile End Kicks’ at 27 and shot it at 37, revisiting emotions from a decade earlier, hopefully with a bit of wisdom. We’re only starting to evaluate and canonize millennial art and music, but there have been far fewer attempts to truly reassess what it all meant, in all its messy grandeur.”

	Like Dunham, Levack examines her early years closely, delighting in detail while avoiding hazy sentimentality. She calls nostalgia her “Trojan horse.” “I’m obsessed with being as specific and authentic as possible, sometimes to the point of annoying collaborators,” she jokes. “If something doesn’t feel exactly like I remember it, it doesn’t feel cinematic. I make these films to find closure and understanding, but also to heighten and romanticize. It’s a dance between authenticity and gloss.”

	Levack has already wrapped the Netflix/Happy Madison comedy “Roommates” — her first U.S. production — and is attached to projects with Spyglass and 21 Laps. Looking ahead, she hopes to develop work on both sides of the 49th parallel. “Canadiana rarely gets localized onscreen,” she notes. “But the more specific you are, the more universal it becomes.”

	— Ben Croll

	Influences: Cameron Crowe, Greta Gerwig, Eric Rohmer, Catherine BreillatAgency: WMEManagement: Artists FirstLegal: Gang Tyre Ramer Brown & Passman

		
			
			
	Harry Lighton
			
										
					Image Credit: Oliver Holms				
					
				

	“Pillion”

	It’s rare, even in the world of independent film, that the arrival of a significant new filmmaker is heralded by the sounds of clanging harnesses and the slick spray from a fresh bottle of lube. But here we are, with director Harry Lighton and his unconventional crowd-pleaser, “Pillion.”

	On its face, the film is a tonally diverse examination of gay male BDSM culture from the eyes of a new convert (Harry Melling). His budding relationship with a strict dominant top (Alexander Skarsgard) causes both to find new and often uncomfortable truths about one another, even as Melling’s eager submissive tries to reconcile his kink with his own self-worth. The Cannes breakout tore through the 2025 festival circuit, delighting audiences by doing the impossible: showing tenderness and discovery while still driving the hard point that fetishes are as much shields from pain as they are avenues to pleasure.

	“One minute it’s making you laugh, and the next it’s making you horny or making you gasp,” Lighton says of his first feature. “There’s as much syrup as there is spice in the film, to keep an audience unfamiliar with this world from running 15 minutes in, when we show an alley blowjob. By then, they’ve already had a bit of a Christmas movie and some nice family dynamics.”

	While Lighton has completed a script about the life of late fashion king Alexander McQueen, co-written with mentor Oliver Hermanus, he’s mulling his next feature outside the queer space.

	“My filmmaking has been squarely informed by my experience of sexuality and trying to reckon with ways in which I do and don’t feel part of both heteronormative and queer culture,” Lighton says. “I’ve emptied my guts as far as exploring where my identity comes from. I want to see what happens next.”

	— Matt Donnelly

	Influences: Paweł Pawlikowski, Oliver Hermanus, Nick Morris (who shot “Pillion”)Agencies: UTA, Sayle Screen (U.K.)

		
			
			
	NB Mager
			
										
					Image Credit: Getty Images for Bentonville Fil				
					
				

	“Run Amok”

	It’s kind of the tagline on my website, but it really is true: I tell stories about the things that keep me up at night,” says NB Mager, whose Sundance-bound feature debut, “Run Amok,” confronts the impact of gun violence on the American psyche. More to the point, the film (which Mager expanded from a proof-of-concept short of the same name) looks at how a community deals with the 10-year anniversary of a school shooting.

	“On the political side of things, I feel like there’s a need to place blame and provide answers. Why does this happen? How do we stop this from happening? Those are all really valid questions, and I’m glad that people are thinking about them,” Mager says. “But for me, coming at it from a creative standpoint, I didn’t feel the pressure to give any sort of prescriptive answer.”

	Mager was born in Israel, but moved to the U.S. young enough to have the suburban American public school experience. Walking a tricky tonal line, she skewers aspects that strike her as upsetting or absurd, like active-shooter drills and earnest theater-kid energy, respectively. (Mager studied acting at the North Carolina School of the Arts before shifting her focus to filmmaking.)

	“I definitely gravitate toward heightened worlds and high-concept ideas,” she says. “I mean, I have a science-fiction project I’m working, but I also have a comedy heist action movie that I’m very excited about.”

	What unites them, according to Mager: “The germ of the idea is always like, I want to grapple with this really challenging subject matter. Maybe it’s the theater person in me, but there’s something about having that more expansive world that allows me to challenge myself in dealing with hard subject matter.”

	— Peter Debruge

	Influences: “Election,” “Promising Young Woman,” “Get Out”Legal: Granderson Des Rochers

		
			
			
	Kristen Stewart
			
										
					Image Credit: Emily Soto				
					
				

	“The Chronology of Water”

	Kristen Stewart says that after the Cannes premiere of her debut feature, “The Chronology of Water,” she was able to slow down a bit and refine her vision even more. “I put two minutes back in. I regraded, I finished the score and I refined the sound design — but when I say ‘refined,’ I don’t mean that I cleaned it up; I just was able to go in and make sure that every final, last stone hadn’t been left unturned.”

	Her passion for cinema, for discourse about art and her film, which stars Imogen Poots, is palpable. Nonlinear and in no way straightforward, “The Chronology of Water” is full of poetic and impressionist sequences. Stewart’s style suits the material, which she adapted from the memoir by Lidia Yuknavitch. Yuknavitch’s book chronicles her horrific childhood abuse, how she found freedom in swimming and her painful journey as a writer.

	“I want to make big commercial poems that are films,” says Stewart. “I really think it’s possible, and I think that everyone wants it. It’s not weird; it’s just that we haven’t done it in a minute, you know?”Stewart spent eight years trying to get this film made. Having become very familiar with formulaic Hollywood movies, she loves the fact that “Water” is at once a very specific story and also a “reality-breaking full dreamy tone poem … for people who’ve been through some fucking shit,” Stewart explains.

	“It just felt like, ‘Oh, do you want to be allowed to take up some space and say stuff?’ That’s why I want to be a director. That’s why it’s hard to do so if you’re a young woman as an actress in this business,” she says. “It’s about repossessing all of the language that surrounds us and inundates our self-worth and the way we see ourselves, and just fucking breaking the back of those words and figuring out your own. So that’s why it was my first movie, and I had to do it. There was no fucking way around it.”

	— Carole Horst

	Influences: Kate Zambreno, Maggie Nelson, Barbara Hammer, Andrei TarkovskyAgency: WMELegal: McKuin Frankel Whitehead

		
			
			
	Walter Thompson-Hernández
			
										
					Image Credit: Kemal Cilengir				
					
				

	“If I Go Will They Miss Me”

	Like the hyphenated last name of its creator, Thompson-Hernández’s debut feature reflects the two sides of his cultural heritage. “My dad is Black, my mom is Mexican,” says the Los Angeles native, whose “If I Go Will They Miss Me” blends street-level realism with fantastical elements extrapolated from Greek mythology. Imagine “Killer of Sheep” meets “Beasts of the Southern Wild.”

	“I grew up under the LAX flight path and always had this fascination with flight. My friends and I would often chase these airplanes,” says the self-taught writer-director. For years, he worked as a global subculture reporter for the New York Times, traveling the world, embedding himself in unfamiliar communities in order to tell their stories — good practice for an approach that is equal parts poet and cultural anthropologist.

	The new film, set to premiere at Sundance in January, reflects his home turf. “I didn’t know my father growing up, but there were other men in my life — you know, my friends, neighbors, uncles, cousins — who sort of stepped up,” he says.

	An earlier short got him invited to the Sundance labs. “The script for the short film was essentially a drawing of a boy standing on a rooftop with wings on both of his sides,” says Thompson-Hernández, who shot two features that both premiered in the past year. 

	The first was the sports doc “Untold: Shooting Stories” about two former NBA basketball players. He also released fiction-based “Kites,” cobbled together in Brazil over the course of five years.

	Basketball means a lot to Thompson-Hernández, who played professionally for the Mexican national team for a few years. “As I dove into arts and filmmaking, I felt almost embarrassed that I had a basketball background, because I didn’t know athletes who were able to do both,” he says. ”Now, I’m so grateful for that experience. I think about the sort of discipline and the approach I have to work with people. As a director, I’m like a coach.”

	Drawing on those days, Thompson-Hernández has written what he calls “a West Coast version of ‘He Got Game’” to make next.

	— Peter Debruge

body:
Jan 2, 2026 10:45am PT	
	

	
		Directors on Their Favorite Films of 2025: From Janicza Bravo to Paul Thomas Anderson to Barry Jenkins and More
	
	
			


			
			
	

									Bravo: Michael Buckner; Getty Images
	

		
	
				

	Acclaimed filmmakers pen essays on the current movies that left them inspired — and sometimes envious.


			
			
	Avatar: Fire and Ash
			
										
					Image Credit: Art Streiber for Variety				
					
				

	By Michael Mann

	Jim Cameron’s third “Avatar,” “Fire and Ash,” is a massive achievement. The towering originality of Jim’s visualization is a given; what makes “Fire and Ash” so potent is its believability.

	After the first two installments, the world knows the origin story of “Avatar.” Jake and Neytiri’s family — including Spider, Quaritch’s son — are refugees sheltering among the Metkayina Reef People with their Maori tattooing and anthropologically complete belief system and pacifist politics. For “Fire and Ash,” Jim added the apostate Ash Clan — Na’vi raiders led by the lethal and seductive Varang (Oona Chaplin). Resources Development Administration is pursuing its imperative of colonization and has Quaritch (Stephen Lang) on point, now reappearing in recombinant form. But there’s dissent within RDA, and Quaritch has a side agenda to regain his son.

	As with Pandora’s biodiversity, Jim has architected different cultures that resonate with authenticity. From the thesis that there are standard patterns within diverse human cultures, Cameron has applied structure principles in building Pandora’s people with the erudition of an anthropologist. Each has rituals, value systems and sympathetic magic with which they interconnect with nature to influence outcomes. 

	Their tribal aesthetics of wardrobe, tattooing and habitation is so specific, you feel these people dress themselves. For the assault of RDA’s colonization, he may have mined patterns from the rape of the Congo by Belgium’s King Leopold or the plight of Brazilian rainforest peoples. These contexts that Jim has built envelop his characters’ rage, frustration, tragedy, aspirations, ambivalence, moments of rapture and vengeance with authenticity. That authenticity amplifies the visceral power of his storytelling.

	Throughout Jim’s propulsive narrative, we experience the Na’vi and humans as more complex people caught in a dire conflict zone in an alien future. And the authenticity of what he’s built makes it resonate with even more visceral power.

	Jim’s artistry, intellect and heavy lifting creates diverse alien biology, anthropology, mechanical engineering, politics, visualization and taut storytelling. It’s extraordinary. Jim began with a blank piece of paper. No writer-director I can think of has invented as large a three-dimensional world of his own imagining as has Jim. “Fire and Ash” on its own is an incredible achievement. There are two more installments to come. From some point in the future, when regarded historically, the whole of “Avatar” will be seen as the magnum opus it truly is.

		
			
			
	All That’s Left of You
			
										
					Image Credit: Michael Buckner				
					
				

	By Janicza Bravo

	A family is uprooted from the place they have always called home and is forced to rebuild elsewhere. “All That’s Left of You” is a timely, multigenerational chronicle of a family amid the backdrop of occupation that seamlessly unfolds with an eye that is unflinching but vulnerable. The work in front of and behind the camera is elegant and urgent. It takes the audience on a journey to define and redefine what home can look like.

	If we’re lucky, there are a handful of films that come out every year that that leave you breathless. Cherien Dabis’ film has done just that.

	There is one scene that is particularly unshakable. On the heels of a sudden curfew, a father is forced to choose what feels like life or death in front of his son. He chooses life to protect his son, but it looks like humiliation, and it forever changes their relationship. The work underlines connection and resilience in the face of injustice. And though my heart was shattered over and over again, I was still left with a sense of hope. A door was opened to a dialogue and a language many of us have struggled to put into words.

	Award-winning filmmaker Janicza Bravo is best known for “Zola,” as well as her work on series suchas “The Bear,” “Too Much,” “Dear White People” and “Poker Face.”

		
			
			
	Blue Moon and Nouvelle Vague
			
										
					Image Credit: Variety via Getty Images				
					
				

	By Taylor Hackford

	Most directors achieve a career-defining moment when they create a film that puts them in Oscar contention. This year, Richard Linklater has done it twice. His delightful tribute to the French New Wave, “Nouvelle Vague,” was shot in Paris, in French, on a shoestring budget. This pre-eminent American independent filmmaker doesn’t speak French, but his intuitive creativity (with a little help from his French-speaking producer, Michèle Pétin) delivers the impossible — a cast of French actors, who not only embody the indelible spirit of the creators of the seminal “Breathless,” but also look exactly like their original counterparts: Jean Luc Godard, Jean Seberg and Jean Paul Belmondo. The movie is so authentic that the French government awarded Linklater its prestigious Chevalier of the Ordre des Arts et des Lettres at the recent American French Film Festival.

	But creating one little gem this year wasn’t enough for Richard Linklater. He’s also presenting us with “Blue Moon,” a jewel-like portrait of America’s greatest lyricist, Lorenz Hart. Again, the director had to find an actor who could embody this unique genius: a gnome-sized, alcoholic, homosexual Jew with a bad combover, whose voluble delivery belies his self-hate and lack of confidence. Of course, Linklater solved this impossible dilemma by casting tall, good-looking WASP, Ethan Hawke, who delivers a brilliant, Oscar-worthy performance — who knew?!

	Both films are small in scope: “Nouvelle Vague” covers the short, 23-day shooting schedule of “Breathless,” so Linklater created the same urgency by shooting in the streets of the City of Lights on an even shorter schedule before the 2024 Paris Olympics; “Blue Moon” takes place in one night, as Lorenz Hart realizes that his long-time collaborator, Richard Rodgers, has supplanted him with Oscar Hammerstein, birthing the greatest songwriting team in Broadway history. The film is set at Sardi’s after the premiere of Rodgers & Hammerstein’s “Oklahoma,” with Linklater satisfying his minuscule budget by shooting on a stage in Dublin, Ireland — you’d never know it.

	Both films personify Richard Linklater’s peerless directing style: Painting genuine human beings on screen — in this case, historical characters who are both palpable and convincing.

	Feature film directors make magic — Richard Linklater is fulfilling his obligation big time.

	Taylor Hackford is an Oscar-winning filmmaker and former president of the Directors Guild of America. His films include “An Officer and a Gentleman,” “The Devil’s Advocate” and “Ray.” He is currently writing his memoir: “Against All Odds,” which will be published by Hachette in the fall of 2026.

		
			
			
	Bugonia
			
										
					Image Credit: Variety via Getty Images				
					
				

	By Julio Torres

	Full disclosure: I am friends with Emma Stone; I have never met Yorgos Lanthimos but I have been a fan since I saw “Dogtooth” in college. Transparency feels like a way of honoring a film about paranoia, gaslighting, lies and manipulation.

	On first watch, my sympathy ping-ponged between Jesse Plemons’ Teddy and Emma’s Michelle. He’s a greasy, probably very unwell conspiracy theorist who has kidnapped a cold and robotic girlboss (my favorite little detail is her putting her trench coat on her shoulders to walk out of her mansion, taking three steps to her car and taking it off). Seeing her calmly listening to his deranged nonsense about how she must make contact with her ship made me sympathize with her even though I’m prone to dislike a calculating pharmaceutical CEO. She is after all, his victim. Her cruelty is revealed later though, followed by a series of violent and desperate escalations from both. Yorgos deliberately keeps his audience in the dark for much of the film and in doing so colors the film with his characters’ uneasy paranoia.

	It’s in the dizzying, meticulous sparring between the protagonists — each working relentlessly to assert their version of the truth — that the heart of the movie lies. Yorgos’ emphasis and restraint in these scenes make us feel like another person in the room trying to make sense of things, going mad in the process. That unnerving synthesizer score which follows the characters takes this sense of immersion even further. The result feels like scrolling online reading vastly different takes on the same issues. At a certain point, one begins to question … is he right? Could she be an alien?

	That’s all I carried into “Sirât.” But within minutes, those associations fell away. This wasn’t rock opera or punk desolation; it was speakers, a laptop, bodies and beats pressed against treacherous ground. My only anchor became the father, Luis (Sergi López in a staggering turn), and his young son. And then — the faces. Faces you’d follow anywhere. I needed that, because filmmaker Oliver Laxe was stripping me of everything I’d entered with: a gentle dissolving of expectation, attachment, even identity, into a kind of purity.

	“Sirât” is one of those rare films that returns cinema to its highest calling, revealing the invisible and creating a space where form, spirit and humanity converge. Every time I asked, “But why…?”, Laxe removed the impulse from my mind. The film put my heart through the ringer, yet looking away was impossible. I trusted he had something golden to offer, but first I had to let go — of analysis, of coolness, of armor.

	As the characters are stripped down, so is the viewer. The landscape expands: sometimes beautiful, sometimes raw, always alive. The desert becomes a character, setting the rhythms of the story and the souls within it. Laxe’s pacing captures what we in SoCal call “desert time.” You can’t impose your city clock on it.

	What moves me most is the film’s spiritual clarity. Laxe doesn’t impose meaning; he uncovers it. He trusts your deepest wisdom and in that trust you feel guided. “Sirât” reminds me that cinema longs to be transcendental. Laxe gets it. He brings it. And I’m renewed by it.

	Alison Anders’ credits include “Gas Food Lodging,” “Grace of My Heart,” a thriving TV career and the upcoming “Paul Is Dead.”

		
			
			
	Sorry, Baby
			
										
					Image Credit: Variety via Getty Images				
					
				

	By Jesse Eisenberg

	About 30 minutes into “Sorry, Baby,” there’s an unremarkable wide shot of an unremarkable house on an unremarkable college-town street.

	What happens next is one of the great directorial flourishes I’ve ever seen: two simple time cuts as the house slips from afternoon to night. In the context of this brilliant, boiling, enigmatic and ultimately heartbreaking movie, those shots are a kick to the gut; you know what’s happening inside that house. I found myself audibly saying, “No, God, no,” and covering my face like I was watching Carrie get drenched in pig’s blood.

	I spent the final hour of the film rapt by Victor’s portrayal of someone wronged but confused, vengeful but scared, loving but aloof. And, annoyingly, I spent that same hour thinking, “I’ll never make something as deft as this.” How is Eva Victor so attuned to the messy, brutal, funny psychology of a person trying to codify their pain, and at the same time so technically assured as a filmmaker? How do they jump through time with such confidence, weave heavy themes with absurdist humor without ever seeming eager, and trust that their subtle, interior performance will translate a full life to an audience?

	And, of course: what can I steal from this movie? How do I say everything I want to say without being obvious, without over-indicating, without flattering the audience into getting it? I loved this movie as much as I envied it. And as my team of psychologists often tell me, deep envy is my highest form of praise.

	Oscar-nominated Jessie Eisenberg’s credits include “When You Finish Saving the World” and “A Real Pain.” His next film is an untitled musical comedy starring Julianne Moore and Paul Giamatti.

		
			
			
	Train Dreams
			
										
					Image Credit: Getty Images				
					
				

	By James Mangold

	The best films are hard to describe. They defy words. They sneer at synopsis. They eclipse plot. They are pure light, emotion and energy.

	Based on the novella by Denis Johnson, Clint Bentley’s sublime film, “Train Dreams,” tracks the life of an ordinary man, a logger and loner, working the great northwest woods in the early 20th century. His name is Robert Grainier and he is played by a magnificent Joel Edgerton, an actor whose work has always been rough, tender and beautiful but, in this role, seems to find room to even further expand.

	We will come to know Robert, traveling through half his life in the first five minutes. Then the film hunkers down, as Robert falls in love with the luminous Gladys (Felicity Jones), the woman he will marry but also the love he must abandon for paying work.

	The deep woods are not just Robert’s place of work or a background. They also serve as a kind of natural cathedral, a world of beauty but also a crucible of loneliness (beautifully realized by cinematographer Adolpho Veloso and scored by Bryce Dessner). It is in these vast woods that Robert will witness a murder that will haunt his life.

	Bentley and writing partner Greg Kwedar populate Robert’s journey with charming forlorn characters. They find solace in each other, however fleeting. Jones shines as Gladys, the love of Robert’s life. William H. Macy is glorious as a wizened old timer who becomes Robert’s true friend. And Kerry Condon dazzles again when she arrives like a cool breeze in the third act.

	Through Robert’s eyes, Bentley and his collaborators reveal a world changing forever and always. The American frontier in all its wildness is literally being cut and felled to build the 20th century.

	“Train Dreams” must be seen and felt. If you’ve already watched it, my work is done. But if you haven’t, I hope this nudges you. “Train Dreams” is not cinematic kale. It is not a history lesson. But yes, it is profoundly good for you.

	Oscar-nominated James Mangold’s credits include “A Complete Unknown,” “Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny,” “Ford v. Ferrari,” “Walk the Line” and has “Star Wars: Dawn of the Jedi” on his slate.

		
			
			
	Wake Up Dead Man: A Knives Out Mystery
			
										
					Image Credit: Getty Images				
					
				

	By Karen Kusama

	Rian Johnson’s third installment in his “Knives Out” whodunnit series might also be its most pleasurable and profound. “Wake Up Dead Man” is tonally fleet-footed, managing to skewer the hypocrisies of modern-day religious cultures while also giving compassionate voice to the naked hope among their brethren. Set in a small-town New York parish, the look of the film is surprisingly dark and stormy, and Rian experiments with his twistiest, most Gothic mystery yet. His freewheeling ensemble of actors fully embrace the assignment: every character embodies both the sane and the ridiculous, and their moral failings (namely the chief culprits of Greed, Wrath and Envy) are drawn with a satisfying and comical humanity. Josh Brolin’s Monsignor Wicks believes a vengeful God is also a just one, but he’s sly enough to “confess” the sin of masturbation while pointing out the virtue of shower gel. And this time around, Daniel Craig’s Benoit Blanc is the sobering and skeptical foil to the sincere true believer in Josh O’Connor’s Father Jud. They engage in a philosophical tug-of-war between doubt and faith, pessimism and hope — and somewhere between those two poles, Rian finds a soulful center punctuated with moments of ineffable grace. In the end, he dares to make this shamelessly entertaining story also a deeply personal one. Sometimes, kindness wins.

	Emmy-nominated Karyn Kusama has directed for such series as ‘Yellowjackets,” “In Treatment,” “Billions” and her feature credits include “Girl Fight” and “Jennifer’s Body.”
