Jan 2, 2026 9:00am PT	
	

	
		Most Anticipated Film Performances of 2026, Ranked: Tom Cruise, Brad Pitt, the Mara Sisters and More
	
	
			


			
			
	

									Warner Bros. / Universal Pictures / A24
	

		
	
				

	The year ahead in movies won’t be simply about spectacle, scale or franchise machinery. It will also be about watching actors attempt to stretch, surprise and sometimes completely reinvent themselves in front of our eyes. 

	Variety‘s annual slate of the most anticipated film performances is defined by momentum and ambition. Legacy stars are stepping back into the arena with something to prove, while a new generation edges closer to that elusive line between “promising” and “arrived.”

	We have icons like Meryl Streep and Denzel Washington returning to familiar archetypes with the weight of history behind them. Elsewhere, performers like Charles Melton and Sadie Sink are chasing the kind of work that reshapes careers rather than simply advances them. Comedians are turning toward drama (Hannah Einbinder). Dramatic actors are flexing comic instincts (Penélope Cruz). And a handful of performers appear determined to make 2026 the year the industry finally catches up to what they’ve been doing all along.

	What makes this year especially dynamic is the sheer range of tones and filmmakers in play. Alejandro G. Iñárritu is pushing Tom Cruise into darkly comic, existential territory. Werner Herzog is orchestrating something gloriously strange with Kate and Rooney Mara at its center. Christopher Nolan is mounting a mythic adaptation of “The Odyssey,” positioning Matt Damon as cinema’s ultimate wanderer. Elsewhere, Boots Riley skewers capitalism through satire, Steven Spielberg returns to alien awe with a sense of menace, and the long-awaited “Peaky Blinders” film looms as either a victory lap or a funeral march for one of television’s most indelible characters.

	These performances aren’t ranked by their award probability, though we expect many will land in that conversation. They’re selected for the choices behind them. Some actors are testing whether they can carry a franchise. Others are trying to prove they’re more than one. A few are simply reminding audiences why their presence on screen still matters as much as ever.

	Whether it’s Christian Bale’s latest interpretation of Frankenstein’s creature with a punk-rock edge or KJ Apa attempting the near-impossible task of embodying the legendary Jimmy Stewart, these are the 65 performances we can’t wait to see, and the ones most likely to dominate conversations long after the credits roll.

	Note: The list is limited to one performer per film, with actors appearing only once, regardless of multiple projects.

	Honorable mentions: Amy Adams (“Klara and the Sun”); Ben Ahlers (“Little Brother”); Javier Bardem (“The Beloved”); Jessica Chastain (“Other Mommy”); Michael Fassbender (“Hope”); Will Ferrell (“Judgment Day”); Ralph Fiennes (“28: Years Later: The Bone Temple”); Jake Gyllenhaal (“In the Grey”); Nicholas Hoult (“How to Rob a Bank”); Caleb Landry Jones (“Dracula: A Love Tale”); Thomasin McKenzie (“The Uprising”); Rosamund Pike (“Wife and Dog”); Julia Roberts (“Panic Carefully”); Ryan Reynolds (“Mayday”); Meg Ryan (“Good Sex”); Cory Michael Smith (“October”); John Turturro (“The Only Living Pickpocket in New York”); Jeremy Allen White (“The Mandalorian and Grogu”)


			
			
	Neve Campbell — ‘Scream 7’
			
										
					Image Credit: Jessica Miglio				
					
				

	Neve is back!

	Campbell’s presence gives “Scream 7” a sense of franchise DNA — and the best-case scenario is a role that treats legacy like story, not decoration. If the film can strike a balance with the series’ meta humor with genuine dread, Campbell can bring some emotional ballast that makes the scares matter.

		
			
			
	Will Poulter — ‘Union County’
			
										
					Image Credit: Sundance				
					
				
	Will Poulter has his share of exceptional work that proves his immense capabilities as an actor (i.e., “Detroit”). Buzz surrounds his upcoming turn in Adam Meeks’ “Union County,” a drama about a man who must attend a court-mandated drug program. Set to premiere at Sundance, it could be the character-driven exploration that allows Poulter to shed remnants of youthful eccentricity in favor of grounded complexity.
		
			
			
	Hannah Einbinder — ‘Teenage Sex and Death at Camp Miasma’
			
										
					Image Credit: Variety via Getty Images				
					
				
	Emmy winner Hannah Einbinder’s move into genre-leaning material invites some curiosity. Written and directed by Jane Schoenbrun and co-starring Gillian Anderson, if Einbinder can balance satire with sincerity, this role could showcase some surprises. It feels like a calculated risk that could pay off in both cultural relevance and critical enthusiasm.
		
			
			
	O’Shea Jackson Jr. — ‘The Shitheads’
			
										
					Image Credit: Chelsea Lauren/Variety/REX/Shutterstock				
					
				
	I’ve wanted Hollywood to offer O’Shea Jackson more, especially after his breakout turn in “Straight Outta Compton.” Written and directed by Macon Blair, “The Shitheads” sounds like it could be abrasive comedy with something sincere underneath, and Jackson is well-suited to that blend. The film co-stars Dave Franco, Mason Thames and Peter Dinklage, and is set to premiere at the Sundance Film Festival. I believe Jackson can deliver in a rowdy comedy without sanding down the edges.
		
			
			
	Olivia Wilde — ‘I Want Your Sex’
			
								
				

	“I Want Your Sex” is a title engineered to stop the scroll, and Olivia Wilde’s return to acting only brings more curiosity. 

	Directed by Gregg Araki and co-starring Cooper Hoffman and Johnny Knoxville, the Sundance-bound project signals something transgressive — an erotic thriller, warped with satire of desire and power. Araki’s taste for queasy intimacy and emotional provocation suggests the film won’t play it safe. The real intrigue is whether Wilde leans into the discomfort and uses the role to challenge audience expectations and reframe how she’s seen onscreen. She’s also busy this year with Tony Gilroy’s “Behemoth!” and another Sundance feature, this time directed by herself, “The Invite,” which she also stars.

		
			
			
	Jenny Slate — ‘Carousel’
			
										
					Image Credit: Getty Images				
					
				
	Jenny Slate has spent years proving she’s more than comedic timing (i.e., “Obvious Child”), and “Carousel” could cement that shift. Written and directed by Rachel Lambert (“Sometimes I Think About Dying”), the Sundance-bound romantic drama follows a divorced doctor (Chris Pine) whose carefully constructed life in Cleveland is upended when his daughter’s debate aspirations and the unexpected return of a past love (Slate) force him to confront his choices and embrace a second chance. Is this an indie that can break out louder than others? Many seem to think so.
		
			
			
	Tom Rhys Harries — ‘Clayface’
			
										
					Image Credit: Getty Images				
					
				
	Tom Rhys Harries stepping into “Clayface” puts him at the center of one of DC Studios’ most compelling wild cards. A character who can be monstrous, tragic and weirdly relatable all at once, Clayface isn’t a standard cape-and-hero gig, rather an anti-hero (or outright villain) whose power is pure nightmare fuel. He uses shape-shifting, body horror and identity-as-weapon. That’s prime territory for a breakout performance because it demands a bit more than swagger. Harries could turn Clayface into the kind of fan-favorite villain audiences obsess over.
		
			
			
	Isabella Rossellini — ‘The Duchess and I’
			
										
					Image Credit: Christopher Polk/Variety				
					
				
	Now officially an Oscar nominee, Isabella Rossellini will play Suzanne Blum in Mike Newell’s “The Duchess and I.” Blum was the enigmatic lawyer who controlled access to the Duchess of Windsor in her final years, a figure both protective and possibly predatory. This is going to bring royal intrigue with Rossellini at the center, and Newell gives her a character study instead of just a supporting turn, bringing a massive amount of excitement.
		
			
			
	Ewan McGregor — ‘Flowervale Street’
			
										
					Image Credit: Getty Images				
					
				

	David Robert Mitchell directing Ewan McGregor? Yes, please.

	A look at a 1980s family noticing bizarre happenings in their neighborhood could build slow, mounting dread and tension. Still without an Oscar nomination on his resume (despite “Moulin Rouge,” “Trainspotting” and more), he’s often most effective when playing decency under pressure — the normal guy who realizes the world isn’t everyday. Opposite Anne Hathaway, if “Flowervale Street” leans into paranoia or horror-adjacent tension, McGregor can anchor it with credibility and warmth, which only makes the darkness hit harder. 

		
			
			
	Sadie Sink — ‘Spider-Man: Brand New Day’
			
										
					Image Credit: Eamonn McCormack/Variety				
					
				
	Saying farewell to “Stranger Things,” Sadie Sink joining the “Spider-Man” machine is instant buzz. She’s the kind of actor who can smuggle emotion into franchise architecture. She’s building the type of résumé that makes an eventual awards push feel inevitable (i.e., “The Whale”). If her role is substantial — and not just a plot device — she could become the movie’s surprise heartbeat, and the grounded human counterweight to multiverse noise alongside star Tom Holland.
		
			
			
	Nick Jonas — ‘Power Ballad’
			
										
					Image Credit: Getty Images				
					
				
	Learning that Paul Rudd will star in John Carney’s “Power Ballad” got most of us excited for the next joint from the director of “Once” and “Begin Again.” Add Nick Jonas to the mix, and the Lionsgate comedy could have laughs, melancholy, nostalgia, ego, regret, and maybe a late-life second chance. 
		
			
			
	Milly Alcock — ‘Supergirl’
			
										
					Image Credit: Parisa Taghizadeh/Warner Bros.				
					
				
	Milly Alcock stepping into the cape as Supergirl is DC Studios’ bet on presence over name recognition. Alcock proved she could command attention in “House of the Dragon,” but playing Kara Zor-El requires balancing power with vulnerability, and strength with hope — a tonal tightrope that can make or break a superhero franchise. Directed by Craig Gillespie, “Supergirl” needs to feel distinct from Superman’s shadow, and Alcock has the charisma to make that happen if the script gives her room to be more than just super.
		
			
			
	Jacob Elordi — ‘The Dog Stars’
			
										
					Image Credit: Variety via Getty Images				
					
				
	Coming off “Frankenstein,” Jacob Elordi continues pushing beyond heartthrob perception, and “The Dog Stars” reads like a project designed to stress-test his dramatic credibility. If it’s a survival story or a mood-driven character study, Elordi’s best lane is playing toughness with a visible crack underneath. The proper performance in the right film can push him to superstardom, especially if the project lands with critics. The 28-year-old Australian actor will also play Heathcliff in Emerald Fennell’s “Wuthering Heights” and reprise his role as Nate Jacobs in the final season of the hit TV show “Euphoria.”
		
			
			
	Zazie Beetz — ‘They Will Kill You’
			
										
					Image Credit: Nina Westervelt for Variety				
					
				
	Zazie Beetz has the rare ability to be magnetic without overselling, perfect for a tension-driven film like “They Will Kill You.” She consistently gets cited as the reason scenes work — and a lead role built around threat and survival could finally put her center stage. If the film balances fear with character depth, Beetz can make it feel specific rather than generic. 
		
			
			
	Nicholas Galitzine — ‘Masters of the Universe’
			
										
					Image Credit: Getty Images				
					
				
	Nicholas Galitzine has the power! Stepping into the shoes (and underwear) of Dolph Lundgren as He-Man has obvious franchise upside: Potential global exposure, instant iconography and a ready-made fan base. Galitzine’s recent work suggests he can do sincerity without being corny, which matters for a property that could easily slip into camp. The anticipation is whether Galitzine can make the hero feel human enough to care about, not just strong enough to pose. 
		
			
			
	Lily-Rose Depp — ‘Werwulf’
			
										
					Image Credit: Corbis via Getty Images				
					
				
	Robert Eggers making a werewolf film was already a headline. Lily-Rose Depp as a key player inside that world, alongside Aaron Taylor-Johnson, adds extra fascination because Eggers tends to demand total commitment and emotional specificity even in myth. She’s been chasing boundary-pushing projects that could reframe her as a serious performer in the right director’s hands. If “Werwulf” blends body horror with tragedy — as Eggers often does brilliantly — Depp could be a force to be reckoned with.
		
			
			
	KJ Apa — ‘Jimmy’
			
										
					Image Credit: Courtesy				
					
				
	James Stewart is an icon who feels impossible to play. That’s what makes KJ Apa’s casting in the biopic “Jimmy” so intriguing. Directed by Aaron Burns, the drama could be a safe tribute or a genuine attempt to locate the darkness beneath Stewart’s aw-shucks charm. Apa seems to have charisma but has yet to have a breakout film role. Could this be his big arrival?
		
			
			
	Anne Hathaway — ‘Verity’
			
										
					Image Credit: Kristina Bumphrey/Variety				
					
				
	Oscar winner Anne Hathaway knows how to weaponize likability, then dismantle it. Directed by Michael Showalter, “Verity” follows writer Lowen Ashleigh (Dakota Johnson), hired to complete bestselling author Verity Crawford’s book series after a mysterious accident. Co-starring Josh Hartnett, the Colleen Hoover adaptation could make Hathaway’s “Verity” a mainstream obsession and the kind of turn that fuels memes, think pieces and awards chatter. She also has roles as Penelope in Christopher Nolan’s “The Odyssey,” reprising her beloved Andy Sachs in “The Devil Wears Prada 2,” the titular character in David Lowery’s “Mother Mary” and “Flowervale Street” opposite Ewan McGregor — all cementing an absolutely massive year. Queen Anne continues to reign.
		
			
			
	Daniel Kaluuya — ‘Misty Green’
			
										
					Image Credit: Getty Images				
					
				
	Daniel Kaluuya, an Oscar winner for “Judas and the Black Messiah,” has an excellent record of choosing material that carries an idea — social tension (“Judas and the Black Messiah”), dread (“Widows”), moral consequence (“Nope”) — without losing human stakes. The upcoming “Misty Green” sounds atmospheric, maybe even genre-adjacent, which is where Kaluuya’s coiled intensity hits hardest. If the film leans toward the psychological or the allegorical, he can make that feel urgent rather than abstract. 
		
			
			
	Natalie Portman — ‘The Gallerist’
			
										
					Image Credit: Courtesy of Getty				
					
				
	Oscar winner Natalie Portman excels when playing a character with a pressure point. Directed by Cathy Yan, “The Gallerist” follows gallerist Polina Polinski preparing for her Art Basel premiere when an art influencer’s viral critique attracts a legendary dealer, igniting the ruthless art world machine. Co-starring Zach Galifianakis, Da’Vine Joy Randolph and Catherine Zeta-Jones, the dark comedy thriller makes perfect terrain for Portman. She’ll also have a role in Lena Dunham’s “Good Sex.”
		
			
			
	Anya Taylor-Joy — ‘Dune: Part Three’
			
										
					Image Credit:  Samir Hussein/WireImage				
					
				
	Emmy nominee Anya Taylor-Joy fully stepping into Alia Atreides has massive upside. Denis Villeneuve’s “Dune” world rewards performers who can play grand ideas without losing the human thread, and Taylor-Joy’s presence is built for that balance. It’s ethereal but cutting, and vulnerable yet dangerous. If “Dune: Part Three” leans into Alia’s complexity, she could become the film’s most fascinating element, especially for viewers ready for a new focal point beyond Paul. This is a blockbuster spectacle with a genuine performance opportunity.
		
			
			
	Ethan Hawke — ‘The Weight’
			
										
					Image Credit: Getty Images				
					
				
	Ethan Hawke, a four-time Oscar nominee, is generating serious awards heat for playing Lorenz Hart in “Blue Moon.” The upcoming drama “The Weight” — directed by Padraic McKinley and co-starring Julia Jones and Russell Crowe — drops him into 1930s Oregon as Samuel Murphy, a widower estranged from his daughter who becomes entangled with gold smugglers and an unscrupulous criminal. It’s Western-adjacent character Hawke that can easily inhabit. If the film leans into silence and weathered faces rather than genre convention, Hawke can build something truly memorable.
		
			
			
	Emma Mackey — ‘The Chronicles of Narnia: The Magician’s Nephew’
			
										
					Image Credit: Getty Images				
					
				
	Greta Gerwig taking on “Narnia” for Netflix automatically raises the artistic stakes, and Emma Mackey landing a key role reads like a director-driven bet on presence. Mackey has the charisma to carry franchise scale without feeling manufactured, which matters in fantasy worlds that can turn actors into walking costumes. If Gerwig brings her key specificity to the material and Mackey is positioned as a central human anchor, this could be a star-making moment.
		
			
			
	Sacha Baron Cohen — ‘Ladies First’
			
										
					Image Credit: Variety via Getty Images				
					
				
	Directed by Thea Sharrock for Netflix, “Ladies Night” is a black-and-white rom-com that follows a male chauvinist who finds himself in an alternate world where the power dynamics of society are altered — a premise loosely inspired by the 2018 French film “I Am Not an Easy Man.” Co-starring Rosamund Pike and Richard E. Grant, the film has the setup for sharp social satire, and Sacha Baron Cohen’s willingness to push material past comfort is the main selling point. If the film skews darker or more biting beneath the comedy, Baron Cohen has the skill to make the laughs land and still leave a bruise.
		
			
			
	Cate Blanchett — ‘Sweetstick’
			
										
					Image Credit: Getty Images				
					
				
	“Sweetstick” follows a mercurial woman with a strange and piercing gift — the ability to see what others most intimately need, often at high personal cost. The premise has a fairy-tale structure with a psychological edge, and two-time Oscar winner Cate Blanchett excels at playing characters who carry burdens that appear to be blessings. Alice Burch’s directorial debut suggests something deceptively gentle, possibly hiding cruelty, and a tonal ambiguity where Blanchett does her most commanding work. Blanchett also has a role in David and Nathan Zellner’s “Alpha Gang” alongside Riley Keough and Chris Pine.
		
			
			
	Channing Tatum — ‘Josephine’
			
										
					Image Credit: Greta Zozula				
					
				
	Despite outstanding turns in “Foxcatcher” and the underrated “Roofman,” It seems Hollywood is still underestimating the great Channing Tatum. Directed by Beth de Araujo and co-starring Gemma Chan, “Josephine” follows 8-year-old Josephine, who accidentally witnesses a crime in Golden Gate Park and acts out in search of a way to regain control of her safety. Tatum proved he can be more than a movie star. A role centered on childhood trauma and powerlessness would test his range and get people to notice. Reprising his version of Gambit in “Avengers: Doomsday” next year will surely get people’s attention as well.
		
			
			
	Daisy Edgar-Jones — ‘Sense and Sensibility’
			
										
					Image Credit: Getty Images for Kering				
					
				
	Jane Austen roles are deceptively hard. Daisy Edgar-Jones built her reputation on intimacy and emotional clarity, which makes her a strong fit for Austen’s romantic volatility. Austen always sells, and Ang Lee’s 1995 “Sense and Sensibility” earned seven Oscar nominations, including best picture — but the anticipation is whether this version from director Georgia Oakley feels fresh and whether Edgar-Jones finds something new inside a character audiences think they already know (which was prominently played by Emma Thompson).
		
			
			
	Kendrick Lamar — ‘Whitney Springs’
			
										
					Image Credit: Mike Coppola/Getty Images				
					
				
	Kendrick Lamar stepping into a feature role is instant curiosity. His artistry is already cinematic. What’s unknown is whether “Whitney Springs” asks him to act against his own persona or lean into it. Either approach has upside if the material is genuine and the direction is disciplined. Directed by “South Park” mastermind Trey Parker, the film follows a young Black man who is interning as a slave re-enactor at a living history museum and discovers that his white girlfriend’s ancestors once owned his. Cultural attention is guaranteed on this one.
		
			
			
	Cameron Diaz — ‘Outcome’
			
										
					Image Credit: Swan Gallet/WWD				
					
				
	Cameron Diaz’s return to acting makes “Outcome” a potential home run before anyone sees a frame. Her star power and comedic timing are undeniable (i.e., “Charlie’s Angels” and “Being John Malkovich”), and a comeback role can generate real momentum if the project lets her do more than just “return.” Directed by Jonah Hill and co-starring Keanu Reeves, the black comedy should give Diaz room to surprise, and Hill’s directorial sensibility tends to balance absurdity with emotional stakes (“Mid 90s”). She also appears in Netflix’s “Back Monday” later this year.
		
			
			
	Christian Bale — ‘The Bride!’
			
										
					Image Credit: Maggie Gyllenhaal/Niko Tavernise/Instagram				
					
				
	Oscar winner Christian Bale consistently embraces a difficult, uncomfortable transformation, and Maggie Gyllenhaal’s Frankenstein reimagining sounds engineered for maximal swing. If “The Bride!” blends politics, horror and musical ambition, that pain of the Creature could land harder than expected. What adds extra intrigue is Bale’s second major play this year in “Madden,” playing Al Davis, a famous public figure. If “The Bride!” works, Bale could be in the conversation twice for completely different reasons. His co-star Jessie Buckley was on this list in 2025.
		
			
			
	Ryan Gosling — ‘Project Hail Mary’
			
										
					Image Credit: Screenshot courtesy YouTube/Amazon MGM				
					
				
	The buzz has already started on this one. Ryan Gosling is a three-time Oscar nominee who thrived playing intelligence under pressure. Andy Weir’s story gives him both. With Phil Lord and Christopher Miller directing, the big question is tone, and if the film can balance humor with genuine dread. Gosling can, and the early word is the film does. If handled right, this crowd-pleaser also plays as serious acting work, generating meme energy and awards chatter simultaneously, which is rare.
		
			
			
	Kristen Stewart — ‘The Wrong Girls’
			
										
					Image Credit: Getty Images for The Gotham Film				
					
				
	Kristen Stewart’s best work lives in the discomfort, where her characters won’t fit inside the story they’re handed. An Oscar nominee for “Spencer” and coming off a strong directorial debut with “The Chronology of Water,” Stewart is a real treat anytime she’s given material with some edges, and “The Wrong Girls,” a Neon comedy by her real-life partner Dylan Meyer, could be an interesting vehicle.
		
			
			
	Caitríona Balfe — ‘A Long Winter’
			
										
					Image Credit: CAITLIN CRONENBERG				
					
				
	Caitríona Balfe is ready for more. Directed by Andrew Haigh (“All of Us Strangers”) and adapted from Colm Tóibín’s short story, “A Long Winter” follows a family high in the mountains preparing for winter when a mother storms out after fighting with her husband, heading to her brother’s distant home as a blizzard engulfs the region. Co-starring Ebon Moss-Bachrach, Kit Connor and Fred Hechinger, Balfe’s performance could resonate with critics who value restraint and the kind of quiet, deliberate work that positions an actor for serious consideration.
		
			
			
	Denzel Washington — ‘Here Comes the Flood’
			
										
					Image Credit: Brian Bowen Smith for Variety				
					
				
	Denzel Washington doesn’t need a comeback. He never left. “Here Comes the Flood” offers the icon a heist film directed by Fernando Meirelles and written by Simon Kinberg. Washington plays a bank guard caught in a deadly game of cons and double crosses alongside Robert Pattinson and Daisy Edgar-Jones. Washington has two Oscars and remains one of the few actors who can elevate any material into something weightier. Will Washington play the mentor, the villain or both?
		
			
			
	Charles Melton — ‘Saturn Return’
			
										
					Image Credit: Gilbert Flores				
					
				
	Charles Melton has been working and building since his breakout in “May December.” In “Saturn Return,” directed by Greg Kwedar, he could have the role that solidifies his place in the movies. The film follows two Chicago college sweethearts (Melton and Rachel Brosnahan) over a decade as they navigate the complexities of adulthood and fate tests their youthful dreams. Also co-starring Will Poulter, Melton has the sensitivity for long-form storytelling, and a decade-spanning character study gives him room to show range. He also has a role in Nicolas Winding Refn’s “Her Private Life.”
		
			
			
	Penélope Cruz — ‘The Invite’
			
										
					Image Credit: Xavi Gordo for Variety				
					
				
	Oscar winner Penélope Cruz (“Vicky Cristina Barcelona”) has the smile that feels like a warning, and the vulnerability that reads as strategy. Directed by Olivia Wilde and written by Rashida Jones and Will McCormack, “The Invite” is an English-language remake of Cesc Gay’s “The People Upstairs.” It follows a married couple experiencing a rough patch who find themselves invited by their neighbors to engage in their weekly orgies. Also starring Seth Rogen, Edward Norton and Wilde, Cruz could balance elegance with volatility in a sex comedy that sounds deliciously watchable and awards-friendly.
		
			
			
	Anthony Ippolito — ‘I Play Rocky’
			
										
					Image Credit: Courtesy of Amazon/MGM				
					
				
	Playing Sylvester Stallone in a film about refusing to sell “Rocky” without starring in it is a high-wire act. But if Peter Farrelly frames the story as an underdog drama with stakes, actor Anthony Ippolito has a real breakout lane, especially if the role emphasizes hunger, pride and desperation over simple mimicry. With Stephan James as Carl Weathers and Jay Duplass as John Avildsen, the supporting cast brings a character-forward approach. The anticipation is whether Ippolito finds the humanity in it all.
		
			
			
	Keke Palmer — ‘I Love Boosters’
			
										
					Image Credit: Gilbert Flores				
					
				
	Keke Palmer has the audience connection and presence that feels automatic. Directed by Boots Riley, “I Love Boosters” follows a group of shoplifters who target a cutthroat fashion maven. Palmer can deliver comedy with bite while grounding the story emotionally (i.e., “Nope”), and Riley’s anti-capitalist sensibility should give her room to swing between humor and heartbreak. Palmer is a star you want to hang out with, even when the character is messy.
		
			
			
	Hugh Jackman — ‘The Death of Robin Hood’
			
										
					Image Credit: Marc Hom for Variety				
					
				
	Revisionist Robin Hood gives Oscar nominee Hugh Jackman a role with built-in mythology and mortality, and he’s excellent at playing strength that’s starting to fail. If the film leans into regret and consequence rather than swashbuckling, Jackman could turn out a surprisingly emotional turn, perhaps similar to what he gave us with “Logan.” What does it cost to be a legend when the legend runs out? For audiences, it’s an easy sell — Jackman in heroic mode — but the real anticipation is how dark (or compelling) it gets.
		
			
			
	Michelle Williams — ‘A Place in Hell’
			
										
					Image Credit: Variety				
					
				

	“She’s gotta win an Oscar one day, right?”

	Michelle Williams is the type of actress who garners that very question by cinephiles and Oscar enthusiasts every year. A five-time Oscar nominee who turns quiet suffering into something piercing but never showy. Written and directed by Chloe Domont (“Fair Play”), “A Place in Hell” follows two women at a high-profile criminal law firm with a setup that could bring moral compromise, ambition and the kind of psychological pressure Domont explored in her debut. Alongside Daisy Edgar-Jones and Andrew Scott, Williams can make that tension feel unnervingly personal. If the film leans into the ethical rot of corporate law (timely!), she can keep it human even as the stakes turn allegorical.

		
			
			
	Cillian Murphy — ‘Peaky Blinders: The Immortal Man’
			
										
					Image Credit: Netflix				
					
				
	Cillian Murphy returning as Tommy Shelby has many in line, ready to throw their money to see it on the big screen. Fresh off an Oscar win for “Oppenheimer,” Murphy has the rare ability that turns any major role into an event. Directed by Tom Harper and written by Steven Knight, “Peaky Blinders: The Immortal Man” continues the series with new additions Rebecca Ferguson, Barry Keoghan and Tim Roth. The anticipation is whether this is a closing chapter or the final self-destruction for the iconic character.
		
			
			
	Emily Blunt — ‘Disclosure Day’
			
										
					Image Credit: Universal Pictures				
					
				
	Emily Blunt is an Oscar nominee (“Oppenheimer”) who’s effective at playing competence under stress. Directed by Steven Spielberg, “Disclosure Day” centers on alien contact, with the trailer posing a pointed question: If you found out we weren’t alone, if someone showed you and proved it to you, would that frighten you? It’s classic Spielberg territory with wonder mixed with suspense. Blunt is the ideal actor to anchor that tension. She can ground the spectacle without diminishing it. Let’s not forget, she’s also in “The Devil Wears Prada 2,” reprising a character we all love.
		
			
			
	John Malkovich — ‘Wild Horse Nine’
			
										
					Image Credit: Getty Images				
					
				
	John Malkovich earned Oscar noms for “Places in the Heart” and “In the Line of Fire” over 30 years ago, and he’s never won — which means he’s precisely the kind of actor the Academy loves to correct when the role is big enough. Martin McDonagh writing for Malkovich is the pairing that could produce something genuinely unsettling. “Wild Horse Nine,” set during the 1973 Chilean coup and following two CIA agents on a trust-testing mission from Santiago to Easter Island, sounds like a breeding ground for paranoia, betrayal and dialogue-driven tension McDonagh does best. The ensemble includes Sam Rockwell, Parker Posey and Steve Buscemi, and if Malkovich’s role carries weight, this could be his J.K. Simmons-in-“Whiplash” or James Coburn a la “Affliction” moment.
		
			
			
	Michelle Mao — ‘Zi’
			
										
					Image Credit: Sundance				
					
				
	Michelle Mao will anchor Kogonada’s latest “Zi,” premiering at the Sundance Film Festival. Written and directed by the auteur, the sci-fi drama follows a young woman in Hong Kong haunted by visions of her future self who meets a stranger who changes the course of her night — and possibly her life. Co-starring Haley Lu Richardson and Jin Ha, the film is Kogonada’s follow-up to “After Yang” and positions Mao as a newcomer capable of carrying philosophical weight. 
		
			
			
	Colman Domingo — ‘Michael’
			
										
					Image Credit: Getty Images				
					
				
	Colman Domingo playing Joe Jackson in Antoine Fuqua’s Michael Jackson biopic invites heat and potential acclaim. A two-time Oscar nominee (“Rustin” and “Sing Sing”), Domingo projects warmth and menace in the same breath, which matters for a figure as controversial as Joe. Starring the King of Pop’s real-life nephew Jaafar Jackson, if the film avoids caricature, Domingo could deliver a turn that becomes the movie’s moral engine. Not a villain, or a saint, but a complicated force shaping genius and trauma. His co-star, Nia Long, was on this list in 2025 before the delay and reshoots. 
		
			
			
	Margot Robbie — ‘Wuthering Heights’
			
										
					Image Credit: Warner Bros				
					
				
	Oscar winner Emerald Fennell’s take on Catherine Earnshaw has the kind of combustible setup that turns a literary role into a full-blown event with romance, cruelty, obsession and ego, all with Robbie at the center. A two-time Oscar nominee for “I, Tonya” and “Bombshell,” Robbie is at her best when a character’s charm and self-destruction are locked in the same room — and this part is built for that. Playing opposite Jacob Elordi only sharpens the pop-culture hook.
		
			
			
	Andrew Garfield — ‘Artificial’
			
										
					Image Credit: Penske Media via Getty Images				
					
				
	Oscar nominee Andrew Garfield playing OpenAI CEO Sam Altman, directed by Luca Guadagnino, could be a timely look at a man changing the world. “Artificial” follows the confusing firing-and-rehiring cycle at OpenAI, where the board gained control and removed Altman before he returned. Garfield excels at ambition laced with vulnerability, and with Monica Barbaro as Mira Murati and Ike Barinholtz as Elon Musk, the film has Oscar energy. The question is whether Guadagnino turns boardroom chaos into something cinematic (and hopefully, not too long a runtime). Garfield will also appear in Ben Gregor’s “The Magic Faraway Tree” and Paul Greengrass’ “The Uprising.”
		
			
			
	Julianne Moore — ‘Untitled Jesse Eisenberg Musical’
			
										
					Image Credit: Alexi Lubomirski for Variety				
					
				
	Julianne Moore playing a shy woman losing herself in community theater sounds like Jesse Eisenberg canon. The Oscar winner excels at characters losing control, and a musical comedy about transformation under an enigmatic director gives Moore room to be funny, vulnerable and slightly unhinged. Co-starring Paul Giamatti, Halle Bailey and Bernadette Peters, the A24 production could be an immersive experience. Moore will also appear in Robert Schwentke’s psychological thriller “Control.”
		
			
			
	Robert Downey Jr. — ‘Avengers: Doomsday’
			
										
					Image Credit: Variety via Getty Images				
					
				

	Marvel’s most significant swing in years is also its simplest pitch. Let’s bring back Robert Downey Jr. 

	While the hook isn’t nostalgia, Downey, once the face of Iron Man, is stepping into the villain Doctor Victor von Doom. If the Russo Brothers balance comic-book scale with character psychology, Downey’s charisma could make Doom feel more than a gimmick. Coming off his Oscar win for “Oppenheimer,” Downey is at his best when he’s threading charm through danger. This is either a franchise reset or a real possible franchise killer. We’re hopeful it’s the former.

		
			
			
	Kara Young — ‘Is God Is’
			
										
					Image Credit: Kristina Bumphrey/Variety				
					
				
	Tony winner Kara Young’s turn in “Is God Is” promises confrontation. Written and directed by Aleshea Harris in her feature debut, the film adapts Harris’ Obie-winning play about twin sisters with disfiguring burn scars who are ordered by their bedridden mother to kill their abusive father. Co-starring Mallori Johnson, Sterling K. Brown, Vivica A. Fox and Janelle Monáe, the Amazon MGM film is said to preserve the source material’s mythic violence. Young’s performance could be physically committed and emotionally unsparing, and make the Broadway darling a household name.
		
			
			
	Andrew Scott — ‘Pressure’
			
										
					Image Credit: Gareth Cattermole/Getty Images f				
					
				
	Andrew Scott has been building toward this moment. It’s a role whose title already promises collapse and prestige. Scott’s gift is showing emotion in real time without turning it into “acting.” His recent work, such as “Blue Moon” and “All of Us Strangers,” has moved him into the Oscar conversation, and a project like Anthony Maras’ period drama “Pressure” could finally break through. With co-stars Brendan Fraser and Kerry Condon, this could be a moment similar to Benedict Cumberbatch’s in “The Imitation Game.” The Irish star will also have a role in Chloe Domont’s “A Place in Hell.”
		
			
			
	Keanu Reeves — ‘The Entertainment System is Down’
			
										
					Image Credit: John Nacion/Variety				
					
				
	I don’t know about you guys, but I’m ready for the Oscars to embrace Keanu Reeves. After being a scene-stealer in Aziz Ansari’s comedy “Good Fortune,” the dream of that happening seems feasible with the star in Ruben Östlund’s “The Entertainment System is Down” opposite Kirsten Dunst, bringing them into the world of social chaos and satire. Reeves’ sincerity colliding with Östlund’s cruelty, and if the film leans into discomfort and class absurdity, Reeves could deliver a funnier performance, stranger and more pointed than audiences expect. He also has a role in Jonah Hill’s “Outcome.”
		
			
			
	Ariana Grande — ‘Focker-in-Law’
			
										
					Image Credit: Getty Images for Universal Pictu				
					
				
	Ariana Grande has spent years proving she can act, and “Focker-in-Law” might be the role that makes Hollywood take her seriously beyond musicals. Following her Oscar-nominated turn in “Wicked” (and an impending one in “Wicked: For Good”), Grande plays the strong-willed woman who appears to be a complete mismatch for Henry Focker, son of Greg and Pam. The premise is pure comedic chaos, and Grande has the timing to hold her own in a franchise built on awkward family dynamics.
		
			
			
	Matt Damon — ‘The Odyssey’
			
										
					Image Credit: Universal Pictures				
					
				
	Christopher Nolan casting Matt Damon as Odysseus could be blockbuster poetry. An Oscar winner known for grounded humanity is playing the ultimate wanderer. Damon’s key asset is credibility. He can sell suffering, cunning and exhaustion without mythological posing. Nolan’s films don’t usually revolve around showy performances, but they reward actors who can carry emotional weight within a big structure (hello “Oppenheimer”). Damon also brings the meta-history of “Matt Damon stuck somewhere” roles, which makes the premise instantly accessible. The cast is also incredibly promising with Tom Holland, Benny Safdie, Zendaya and more. Damon also has Netflix’s “The Rip” in the first half of the year alongside his best friend Ben Affleck.
		
			
			
	Scarlett Johansson — ‘Paper Tiger’
			
										
					Image Credit: Getty Images 				
					
				

	Many of us die-hard James Gray fans are waiting for his big Oscar vehicle. “Paper Tiger” could be it.

	Scarlett Johansson, a two-time Oscar nominee, excels at duality, projecting control while quietly signaling fracture. If the film plays as a corporate thriller, political drama or psychological pressure cooker, Johansson, alongside co-stars Adam Driver and Miles Teller, has the precision to make the stakes feel personal rather than generic. This could be the kind of role that rewards a complete emotional arc, and one that can linger beyond plot mechanics. 

		
			
			
	Dominic Sessa — ‘Tony’
			
										
					Image Credit: Wheaton Mahoney				
					
				
	Dominic Sessa arrives at “Tony” with expectations already attached. Directed by Matt Johnson (“BlackBerry”) and written by Todd Bartels and Lou Howe, the A24 Anthony Bourdain biopic follows the young chef during the summer of 1976 in Provincetown, Massachusetts — a formative, life-changing period documented in “Kitchen Confidential.” Co-starring Antonio Banderas, Emilia Jones and Leo Woodall, the film explores Bourdain’s early years working in seafood restaurants. Following his breakout in “The Holdovers,” Sessa’s naturalism could bring something more complex if the film gives him space to challenge himself.
		
			
			
	Jeremy Strong — ‘The Social Reckoning’
			
										
					Image Credit: Getty Images				
					
				
	If Aaron Sorkin’s sequel “The Social Reckoning” represents the next evolution of tech anxiety on screen, Jeremy Strong feels like a deliberate choice. He’s a performer who treats obsession as a belief system. The Oscar nominee and Emmy winner can be magnetic when the material matches his intensity, and stepping into Mark Zuckerberg’s shoes — following Jesse Eisenberg’s Oscar-nominated turn in 2010 — gives him plenty of combustible ground. Paired with Jeremy Allen White and Mikey Madison, and assuming the film leans into political and ethical friction, Strong’s refusal to sand down edges could place him at the center of the conversation. Love him or resist him, this is a performance people will talk about.
		
			
			
	Zendaya — ‘The Drama’
			
										
					Image Credit: A24				
					
				
	Set to be distributed by A24, “The Drama” follows Emma Harwood (Zendaya), a bookstore clerk, and Charlie Thompson (Robert Pattinson), a museum director, whose relationship is shaken days before their wedding when one partner discovers unsettling truths about the other. The Emmy winner is still chasing her first Oscar nomination, and this feels like the project that could get her there if it’s as psychologically sharp as the title suggests. She’s also back as MJ in “Spider-Man: Brand New Day” and stepping into Christopher Nolan’s “The Odyssey” as Athena. “The Drama” reads like the grown-up swing by the young star.
		
			
			
	Sebastian Stan — ‘Fjord’
			
										
					Image Credit: AFP via Getty Images				
					
				
	Coming off his first Oscar bid for “The Apprentice,” Sebastian Stan has been chasing austerity, and “Fjord” — directed by Cristian Mungiu and co-starring Renate Reinsve — puts him squarely in the territory where discomfort becomes art. The film follows an immigrant Romanian family living in Norway who become subject to an investigation. It’s Mungiu’s terrain that shows systems that crush people, and the moral ambiguity presented without sentiment. Stan thrives when he’s stripped of charm, and this setup should let him work in a register that’s more Dardenne brothers than Marvel. The question is not whether he can handle it, it’s whether American audiences will follow him somewhere this seemingly unforgiving.
		
			
			
	Kate Mara and Rooney Mara — ‘Bucking Fastard’
			
										
					Image Credit: Katie Jones/WWD				
					
				
	Two talented sisters playing synchronized twins under Werner Herzog is the pitch that sells itself. Written and directed by Herzog, “Bucking Fastard” follows twin sisters Jean and Joan Holbrooke who, in search of an imaginary land where true love is possible, start digging a tunnel through a mountain range. If the characters share an obsession and Herzog leans into myth over realism, this could be eerie, funny, unsettling and weirdly moving. Whether Kate and Rooney Mara can create a single shared presence while still feeling like two distinct human beings will be what lingers until we see it.
		
			
			
	Brad Pitt — ‘The Adventures of Cliff Booth’
			
										
					Image Credit: ©Columbia Pictures/courtesy Everett Co / Everett Collection				
					
				
	David Fincher directing a Quentin Tarantino script about Cliff Booth is instant film-geek rapture. It’s also a fascinating challenge for Pitt, who won the Oscar for best supporting actor playing Booth in “Once Upon a Time in Hollywood” (2019). Fincher tends to strip vanity from stars, while Tarantino weaponizes it. That tension could turn Pitt’s easygoing stuntman into something coiled and volatile, especially if the story leans into Hollywood’s rot instead of its romance. Pitt’s also reuniting with David Ayer for “Heart of the Beast” later this year.
		
			
			
	Meryl Streep — ‘The Devil Wears Prada 2’
			
								
				
	Miranda Priestly endures as one of Meryl Streep’s most quotable creations, and now she’s being revisited with purpose. The three-time Oscar winner, with 21 nominations, has always excelled at turning authority into loneliness and comedy into cruelty. With David Frankel back directing and Anne Hathaway, Emily Blunt and Stanley Tucci returning, the fascination lies in watching Streep recalibrate Miranda for a world that commodifies icons and discards them just as quickly. Fashion has changed. Power has changed. The question is whether Miranda has.
		
			
			
	Pedro Pascal — ‘Behometh!’
			
										
					Image Credit: Jeff Spicer/Getty Images				
					
				
	Pedro Pascal has become a rare modern movie star whose name alone signals both mainstream reach and emotional credibility. “Behometh!” (exclamation included) could be something big, strange or swaggering. Pascal is unusually adept at giving spectacle a beating heart. His gift is making toughness look exhausted and tenderness feel hard-earned. Under the writing and direction of Tony Gilroy (“Michael Clayton”), the project carries the promise of character-first ambition. Pascal also has an enormous year ahead, including “Avengers: Doomsday” as Mister Fantastic, a return to “Star Wars: The Mandalorian and Grogu,” and the possibility of Todd Haynes’ “De Noche,” now in development.
		
			
			
	Tom Cruise — ‘Digger’
			
										
					Image Credit: Getty				
					
				
	Four-time Oscar nominee Tom Cruise hasn’t worked with a director this uncompromising in years. Alejandro G. Iñárritu’s “Digger” casts Cruise as Digger Rockwell in a dark comedy co-written with Sabina Berman, Alexander Dinelaris Jr. and Nicolás Giacobone. Alongside Jesse Plemons, Sandra Hüller and John Goodman, the film could push Cruise toward intensity rather than pure stunt mastery. Coming immediately after his Honorary Oscar, will he go the way of Paul Newman and win an overdue statuette? The universe would love nothing more.

Island Boys' Franky Venegas
                          Credit or Debit?!?
                          Alleged Fentanyl Residue on Card Led to Arrest

                            9:56 AM PST
                                                                            
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          One half of the Island Boys got locked up right before the new year started ... and now we have a better idea why.
      
    
          TMZ broke the news ... Franky Venegas was arrested again in Florida for alleged drug-related offenses and is currently behind bars.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                                  
      
    
          According to a sheriff's report we just obtained ... Franky and his female companion were pulled over for a routine traffic stop ... and were allegedly acting super suspicious.
      

          Deputies searched the car, per the report ... and allegedly found unprescribed Zolpidem tartrate -- basically Ambien -- in a baggy with other pills that were prescribed to the woman. Deputies also allegedly found drug paraphernalia that tested positive for fentanyl -- including Franky's debit card, which allegedly was coated in white powder that tested positive for fentanyl, and a cut straw.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                                  
      
    
          Franky was booked into the Collier County Jail in Naples Wednesday night on one count of drug paraphernalia, posing for a fresh mug shot ... face tattoos and all. The woman was booked for the Zolpidem tartrate since there was no prescription.
      
    
          As we reported ... Franky had no bond, as he was on a hold since he's already out on bond from a February arrest for delivering/possessing/selling a firearm with an altered serial number.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                                  
      
    
          Franky rose to fame in 2021 with brother Alex after their viral hit, "I'm an Island Boy."
      
    
          He's previously been arrested for domestic battery, reckless driving, and driving without a license.
